Lovecraft](/article/en/H._P._Lovecraft), [Edgar Allan Poe](/article/en/Edgar_Allan_Poe), [Helen Hunt Jackson](/article/en/Helen_Hunt_Jackson), [Khalil Gibran](/article/en/Khalil_Gibran), [Mary Higgins Clark](/article/en/Mary_Higgins_Clark), [Amelia Atwater-Rhodes](/article/en/Amelia_Atwater-Rhodes), [Jack Kerouac](/article/en/Jack_Kerouac) and [Theodor Seuss Geisel](/article/en/Dr._Seuss), better known as "Dr. Seuss". Famous painters from Massachusetts include [Winslow Homer](/article/en/Winslow_Homer) and [Norman Rockwell](/article/en/Norman_Rockwell); many of the latter's works are on display at the [Norman Rockwell Museum](/article/en/Norman_Rockwell_Museum) in Stockbridge. Massachusetts is an important center for the performing arts. It has the [Boston Symphony Orchestra](/article/en/Boston_Symphony_Orchestra), [Boston Pops Orchestra](/article/en/Boston_Pops_Orchestra) the [Cape Cod Symphony Orchestra](/article/en/Cape_Cod_Symphony_Orchestra) in Barnstable, the [New Bedford Symphony Orchestra](/article/en/New_Bedford_Symphony_Orchestra), and the [Springfield Symphony Orchestra](/article/en/Springfield_Symphony_Orchestra). [Tanglewood](/article/en/Tanglewood) in western Massachusetts is a music venue that hosts the Tanglewood Music Festival and Tanglewood Jazz Festival, and is the annual host for the Boston Symphony Orchestra. Other performing arts and theater organizations include the [Boston Ballet](/article/en/Boston_Ballet), the [Boston Lyric Opera](/article/en/Boston_Lyric_Opera), and the Lenox-based [Shakespeare & Company](/article/en/Shakespeare_%26_Company_(Massachusetts)). Massachusetts has produced musicians of many contemporary genres, such as the classic rock bands [Aerosmith](/article/en/Aerosmith) and [Boston](/article/en/Boston_(band)), the proto-punk band the [Modern Lovers](/article/en/The_Modern_Lovers), the new wave band the [Cars](/article/en/The_Cars), and the alternative rock band [Pixies](/article/en/Pixies). The state has also been the birthplace of the rock bands [Staind](/article/en/Staind), [Godsmack](/article/en/Godsmack), and [Highly Suspect](/article/en/Highly_Suspect), since these bands all were formed in Massachusetts cities such Springfield, Lawrence, and Cape Cod respectively. Film events in the state include the [Boston Film Festival](/article/en/Boston_Film_Festival), the [Boston International Film Festival](/article/en/Boston_International_Film_Festival), and a number of smaller film festivals in various cities throughout Massachusetts. Massachusetts has many museums and historical sites, including the [Clark Art Institute](/article/en/Clark_Art_Institute), the [Museum of Fine Arts, Boston](/article/en/Museum_of_Fine_Arts,_Boston), the [Institute of Contemporary Art, Boston](/article/en/Institute_of_Contemporary_Art,_Boston), and the [DeCordova](/article/en/DeCordova) contemporary art and sculpture museum in Lincoln, and the [Maria Mitchell Association](/article/en/Maria_Mitchell_Association) in Nantucket includes several observatories, museums, and an aquarium. Historically themed museums and sites such as the [Springfield Armory National Historic Site](/article/en/Springfield_Armory_National_Historic_Site) in Springfield, Boston's [Freedom Trail](/article/en/Freedom_Trail), and nearby [Minute Man National Historical Park](/article/en/Minute_Man_National_Historical_Park), both of which preserve many sites important during the American Revolution, the [Lowell National Historical Park](/article/en/Lowell_National_Historical_Park), which focuses on some of the earliest mills and canals of the Industrial Revolution in the US, the [Black Heritage Trail](/article/en/Black_Heritage_Trail) in Boston, which includes important African-American and abolitionist sites in Boston, and the [New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park](/article/en/New_Bedford_Whaling_National_Historical_Park) all showcase various periods of Massachusetts's history. [Plymouth Rock](/article/en/Plymouth_Rock), marks the disembarkation site of the Mayflower Pilgrims who founded Plymouth Colony in December 1620. [Plimoth Patuxet Museums](/article/en/Plimoth_Patuxet) and [Old Sturbridge Village](/article/en/Old_Sturbridge_Village) are two open-air or "living" museums in Massachusetts, recreating life as it was in the 17th and early 19th centuries, respectively. Boston's annual [St. Patrick's Day](/article/en/St._Patrick%27s_Day) parade and "Harborfest", a week-long Fourth of July celebration featuring a fireworks display and concert by the Boston Pops as well as a turnaround cruise in Boston Harbor by the [USS Constitution](/article/en/USS_Constitution), are popular events. The New England Summer Nationals, an auto show in Worcester, draws tens of thousands of attendees every year. The [Boston Marathon](/article/en/Boston_Marathon) is also a popular event in the state drawing more than 30,000 runners and tens of thousands of spectators annually. Long-distance hiking trails in Massachusetts include the [Appalachian Trail](/article/en/Appalachian_Trail), the [New England National Scenic Trail](/article/en/New_England_National_Scenic_Trail), the [Metacomet-Monadnock Trail](/article/en/Metacomet-Monadnock_Trail), the [Midstate Trail](/article/en/Midstate_Trail), and the [Bay Circuit Trail](/article/en/Bay_Circuit_Trail). Other outdoor recreational activities in Massachusetts include sailing and yachting, freshwater and deep-sea fishing, whale watching, downhill and cross-country skiing, and hunting. Massachusetts is one of the states with the largest percentage of Catholics. It has many sanctuaries such as the [National Shrine of The Divine Mercy](/article/en/National_Shrine_of_The_Divine_Mercy) (Stockbridge, Massachusetts). ## Media There are two major television media markets located in Massachusetts. The Boston/Manchester market is the fifth-largest in the United States. The other market surrounds the Springfield area. [WGBH-TV](/article/en/WGBH-TV) in Boston is a major public television station and produces national programs such as [Nova](/article/en/Nova_(TV_series)), [Frontline](/article/en/Frontline_(U.S._TV_program)), and [American Experience](/article/en/American_Experience). The [Boston Globe](/article/en/The_Boston_Globe), [Boston Herald](/article/en/Boston_Herald), [Springfield Republican](/article/en/The_Republican_(Springfield,_Massachusetts)), and the [Worcester Telegram & Gazette](/article/en/Telegram_%26_Gazette) are Massachusetts's largest daily newspapers. In addition, there are many community dailies and weeklies. The [Associated Press](/article/en/Associated_Press) maintains a bureau in Boston, and local news wire the [State House News Service](/article/en/State_House_News_Service) feeds coverage of state government to other Massachusetts media outlets. There are a number of major AM and FM stations which serve Massachusetts, along with many more regional and community-based stations. Some colleges and universities also operate campus television and radio stations, and print their own newspapers. ## Health Massachusetts generally ranks highly among states in most health and disease prevention categories. In 2015, the [United Health Foundation](/article/en/United_Health_Foundation) ranked the state as third-healthiest overall. Massachusetts has the most doctors per 100,000 residents (435.38), the second-lowest infant mortality rate (3.8), and the lowest percentage of uninsured residents (children as well as the total population). According to [Business Insider](/article/en/Business_Insider), commonwealth residents have an average life expectancy of 80.41 years, the fifth-longest in the country. 36.1% of the population is overweight and 24.4% is obese, and Massachusetts ranks sixth-highest in the percentage of residents who are considered neither obese nor overweight (39.5%). Massachusetts also ranks above average in the prevalence of binge drinking, which is the 20th-highest in the country. The nation's first [Marine Hospital](/article/en/Marine_Hospital_Service) was erected by federal order in Boston in 1799. There are currently a total of 143 hospitals in the state. According to 2015 rankings by U.S. News & World Report, Massachusetts General Hospital is ranked in the top three in two health care specialties. [Massachusetts General Hospital](/article/en/Massachusetts_General_Hospital) was founded in 1811 and serves as the largest teaching hospital for nearby Harvard University. The state of Massachusetts is a center for medical education and research including Harvard affiliates [Brigham and Women's Hospital](/article/en/Brigham_and_Women%27s_Hospital), [Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center](/article/en/Beth_Israel_Deaconess_Medical_Center), and [Dana–Farber Cancer Institute](/article/en/Dana%E2%80%93Farber_Cancer_Institute) as well as the [New England Baptist Hospital](/article/en/New_England_Baptist_Hospital), [Tufts Medical Center](/article/en/Tufts_Medical_Center), and [Boston Medical Center](/article/en/Boston_Medical_Center) which is the primary teaching hospital for Boston University. The [University of Massachusetts Chan Medical School](/article/en/University_of_Massachusetts_Chan_Medical_School) is located in Worcester. The [Massachusetts College of Pharmacy and Health Sciences](/article/en/Massachusetts_College_of_Pharmacy_and_Health_Sciences) has two of its three campuses in Boston and Worcester. ## Sports Massachusetts is home to five major league professional sports teams: eighteen-time NBA Champions [Boston Celtics](/article/en/Boston_Celtics), nine-time World Series winners [Boston Red Sox](/article/en/Boston_Red_Sox), six-time Stanley Cup winners [Boston Bruins](/article/en/Boston_Bruins), six-time Super Bowl winners [New England Patriots](/article/en/New_England_Patriots), and five-time MLS Cup finalists [New England Revolution](/article/en/New_England_Revolution). In the late 19th century, the Olympic sports of basketball and volleyball were invented in the Western Massachusetts cities of [Springfield](/article/en/Springfield,_Massachusetts) and [Holyoke](/article/en/Holyoke,_Massachusetts), respectively. The [Basketball Hall of Fame](/article/en/Naismith_Memorial_Basketball_Hall_of_Fame) is a major tourist destination in the City of Springfield and the [Volleyball Hall of Fame](/article/en/Volleyball_Hall_of_Fame) is located in Holyoke. The [American Hockey League](/article/en/American_Hockey_League) (AHL), the NHL's development league, is headquartered in Springfield. Several universities in Massachusetts are notable for their collegiate athletics. The state is home to two Division I FBS teams, [Boston College](/article/en/Boston_College_Eagles) of the Atlantic Coast Conference, and FBS Independent [University of Massachusetts at Amherst](/article/en/UMass_Minutemen_football). FCS play includes [Harvard University](/article/en/Harvard_Crimson_football), which competes in the famed [Ivy League](/article/en/Ivy_League), and [College of the Holy Cross](/article/en/Holy_Cross_Crusaders_football) of the Patriot League. [Boston University](/article/en/Boston_University), [Northeastern University](/article/en/Northeastern_University), [UMASS Lowell](/article/en/UMass_Lowell), [Stonehill College](/article/en/Stonehill_College), and [Merrimack College](/article/en/Merrimack_College) also participate in Division I athletics. Many other Massachusetts colleges compete in lower divisions such as Division III, where [MIT](/article/en/MIT_Engineers), [Tufts University](/article/en/Tufts_University), [Amherst College](/article/en/Amherst_College), [Williams College](/article/en/Williams_College), and others field competitive teams. Massachusetts is also the home of rowing events such as the [Eastern Sprints](/article/en/Eastern_Sprints) on [Lake Quinsigamond](/article/en/Lake_Quinsigamond) and the [Head of the Charles Regatta](/article/en/Head_of_the_Charles_Regatta). A number of major golf events have taken place in Massachusetts, including nine U.S. Opens and two [Ryder Cups](/article/en/Ryder_Cup). Massachusetts has produced several successful Olympians including [Thomas Burke](/article/en/Thomas_Burke_(athlete)), [James Connolly](/article/en/James_Connolly_(athlete)), and [John Thomas](/article/en/John_Thomas_(high_jumper)) (track and field); [Butch Johnson](/article/en/Butch_Johnson) (archery); [Nancy Kerrigan](/article/en/Nancy_Kerrigan) (figure skating); [Todd Richards](/article/en/Todd_Richards_(snowboarder)) (snowboarding); [Albina Osipowich](/article/en/Albina_Osipowich) (swimming); [Aly Raisman](/article/en/Aly_Raisman) (gymnastics); [Patrick Ewing](/article/en/Patrick_Ewing) (basketball); [Stephen Nedoroscik](/article/en/Stephen_Nedoroscik) (pommel horse); as well as [Jim Craig](/article/en/Jim_Craig_(ice_hockey)), [Mike Eruzione](/article/en/Mike_Eruzione), [Bill Cleary](/article/en/Bill_Cleary), [Keith Tkachuk](/article/en/Keith_Tkachuk) (ice hockey). ## See also - [Index of Massachusetts-related articles](/article/en/Index_of_Massachusetts-related_articles) - [Outline of Massachusetts](/article/en/Outline_of_Massachusetts) - [Massachusetts Bay Colony](/article/en/Massachusetts_Bay_Colony) - [New England](/article/en/New_England) - [USS Massachusetts](/article/en/USS_Massachusetts), 8 ships - [USRC Massachusetts](/article/en/USRC_Massachusetts), 2 ships
